CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 5-3;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG Mr. PERSON is a NORP national and was born in DATE . He was formerly a regular army officer and as such last served in the NORP forces stationed in GPE with the rank of senior captain ( capitaine - commandant ) . He and his family now live in GPE and the NORP authorities have requested his extradition .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , ORG ( commission judiciaire ) of ORG " A " , sitting at GPE , ordered the applicant ’s arrest and charged him with embezzlement of ORG funds . ORG was chaired by Mr. PERSON Even , a senior deputy auditeur militaire , who had questioned Mr. PERSON on DATE , and it said that its decision had been taken in view of the seriousness of the charges and the need to take statements from certain witnesses before the applicant could exert influence on them .
On his arrest TIME , the applicant lodged an application for his immediate release but on DATE ORG , again chaired by Mr. PERSON Even , confirmed the order in question on the same grounds .

CARDINAL . ORG DATE , Mr. PERSON submitted to ORG a second application for his release . On DATE , ORG , after having heard the views of another deputy auditeur militaire , Mr. PERSON , declared the application admissible but ill - founded . ORG observed that during the preliminary investigation ORG had exclusive jurisdiction to hear such applications and determine whether or not detention should be ordered . It also found that the initial arrest warrant had been lawful .
The applicant immediately appealed to ORG sitting in GPE , which dismissed the appeal on DATE , upholding the contested judgment on every point .
On DATE , ORG , again chaired by Mr. PERSON Even , confirmed the arrest order for the second time .

On DATE , the applicant appealed to ORG against the judgment of ORG . He relied inter alia on paragraph CARDINAL of LAW , which provides that " save for offences discovered while being committed , no one may be arrested except pursuant to an order issued by a judge , which shall state the grounds on which it is based " . He argued that neither ORG nor any of its members had the status of judge or possessed the independence and impartiality inherent in such status . In particular , an auditeur militaire carried out his duties under the supervision and direction of the Minister of ORG ; he combined the functions of public prosecutor and investigating judge ; his interests as prosecutor and those of the remand prisoner or defendant were directly opposed ; and he alone was vested with the power of decision , since he was not bound by the dissenting opinion of either or both of the officers designated to sit on ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

On DATE , ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . As regards the submission based on LAW , it held that paragraph CARDINAL had to be read in the light of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . In this context the term " judge " therefore meant a body on which judicial powers were conferred by the provisions governing military criminal procedure . Articles DATE and CARDINAL of the Code of Military Criminal Procedure , adopted under LAW of DATE , empowered ORG to issue arrest warrants . The drafting history showed that the auditeur militaire who chaired ORG performed the function of an investigating judge , in which capacity he was by definition independent .

CARDINAL . ORG In the meantime , on CARDINAL DATE , Mr. PERSON had requested ORG to order his release on the ground that ORG had no power to issue and then confirm the warrant of DATE . On DATE , ORG declared this third application inadmissible on the ground that it was incompatible with the principle of res judicata , which applied to the decision of DATE . Before making its ruling , ORG had heard the views of the public prosecutor in the person of Mr. PERSON Even . The applicant immediately appealed to ORG , which dismissed his appeal on DATE as inadmissible and in any event ill - founded .
CARDINAL . ORG A fourth application , on DATE , likewise failed . On DATE , ORG dismissed the application on similar grounds , after having heard the views of Mr. PERSON Even .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , the applicant ’s lawyer had written direct to the auditeur général , who , on DATE , sent him the following reply ( translated from the NORP original ) :

" With reference to the application of DATE for PERSON to be released on bail ... , I have the honour to inform you that , having studied the application , I consider that there are not sufficient grounds for the question of his continued detention to be determined by my office under LAW .

However , I have asked the auditeur militaire of ORG to bring the case before the Court Martial as quickly as possible in order to enable that court to determine the merits and , at the same time , decide on any application for release . ... "

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , the senior deputy auditeur militaire , Mr. PERSON , issued a summons for the applicant to appear before ORG at GPE on DATE . On DATE , ORG ordered the applicant ’s release and adjourned the case sine die .

The trial proceedings resumed on DATE following a further summons , signed this time by Mr. PERSON ( on DATE ) . On DATE , the Court Martial agreed to allow Mr. PERSON to give evidence , under oath . Since the defence objected , ORG decided to join the issue to the merits . However , it elected to hear Mr. PERSON Even immediately .

DATE , the defendant appealed against this decision , but on DATE agreed that the proceedings should continue . In its decision of CARDINAL DATE , the Court Martial based its conclusion inter alia on Mr. PERSON ’s statements , which it ruled were admissible . It sentenced the applicant to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment and a fine of MONEY ( BF ) for forgery , uttering forged documents and embezzlement of ORG funds .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , the applicant appealed to ORG , which ruled on his CARDINAL appeals in a single judgment of DATE .

In the first place , ORG quashed the decision of CARDINAL DATE concerning Mr. PERSON ’s testimony , on the ground that it did not give adequate reasons . It noted in addition that Mr. PERSON , acting not as investigating judge but as representative of the public prosecutor , had taken certain steps in the prosecution , and in particular had issued the summons of DATE . This meant that he had become a party to the proceedings and accordingly could not appear as a witness . His testimony should therefore have been disregarded .

On the merits , ORG reduced the sentence to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment and a fine of CARDINAL BF . It ordered that the applicant be dismissed the service ( LAW ) but , unlike the court below , did not order his immediate arrest .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , ORG dismissed appeals on points of law which the public prosecutor and Mr. PERSON had entered against the judgment of ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG By LAW , first paragraph , of the LAW , " special laws shall regulate the organisation of military courts , their powers , the rights and obligations of their members and the terms of office of the latter " .
Military criminal procedure is governed principally by LAW ) of DATE and the Code of Military Criminal Procedure ( PERSON ) of DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG The auditeur militaire heads the auditeur militaire ’s office of a particular court martial . He is a member of the judiciary , and consequently is not subject to the military chain of command . The same is true of the senior deputies ( such as Mr. PERSON ) and the deputies ( such as Mr. PERSON ) , who assist the auditeur militaire .
Auditeurs militaires and their deputies , however , are not judges within the meaning of LAW . The King , who appoints them , may also dismiss them ( LAW ) . They are therefore not irremovable .

They are hierarchically subordinate to the auditeur général at ORG and to the Minister of ORG , but it is not disputed that in practice they are wholly independent in the performance of their duties .
CARDINAL . ORG The auditeur militaire and his deputies discharge the functions of :
( a ) senior police officers ( officiers de police judiciaire - DATE of the PERSON ) ;

( b ) investigating judges , vested with powers identical to those of civilian investigating judges and which each individual exercises either alone or as chairman of ORG ( Article CARDINAL of the LAW and paragraph CARDINAL below ) ;
( c ) members of the public prosecutor ’s office , acting as prosecuting counsel before the courts martial , subject to the supervision and direction of the auditeur général ( LAW ) .
The Code of Military Criminal Procedure thus derogates from LAW , which prohibits such plurality of functions " except in the cases prescribed by law " .

CARDINAL . ORG However , as a consequence of the PERSON judgment given by ORG DATE ( Series A no . CARDINAL ) , the auditeur général issued the following instructions on DATE ( Circular no . CARDINAL ) :

" ... ORG at ORG has informed me of his view that , in the light of the Schiesser judgment , it is absolutely essential to ensure that , in cases where a preliminary investigation is held , particularly those in which the accused is placed in detention on remand , the judicial officer who acts as prosecuting counsel before the court martial should not be the one who conducted the preliminary investigation .

I have explained to ORG at ORG why in many circumstances , in view of the limited number of auditeurs militaires and deputies , it will no doubt be physically impossible to comply with the rule he wishes to have applied , but have told him that the rule generally will be applied in future .

Pending a solution which will inevitably require legislative reform , I would therefore ask you to ensure that to the fullest extent possible , particularly in cases where the accused is held in detention on remand , the rule laid down by ORG at ORG is applied . "

In subsequent instructions issued on DATE , the auditeur général confirmed and clarified the distinction to be maintained between investigation and prosecution , " pending the necessary legislative reforms " :

" ... It has been held by ORG that a judge who may be required to act in a given case as prosecuting counsel does not afford the guarantees of independence and impartiality necessary for the performance of the judicial acts inherent in the process of investigation .

This case - law prompted my circular ( no . CARDINAL ) of CARDINAL DATE . I now consider that the time has come to take a further step towards separating the processes of investigation and prosecution . That is the purpose of the following instructions .

In all cases in which the auditeur militaire has exercised the judicial powers of investigating judge ( e.g. arrest warrant , hearing of witnesses under oath , search warrant , seizure , body search , or appointment of an expert by ORG ) , the investigation and the prosecution must be conducted by different judicial officers .
I would ask you :
CARDINAL . to implement forthwith the instructions in this circular ;
CARDINAL . to send to me by DATE a detailed report on the practical application of these instructions , on any problems to which such application has given rise , etc .
CARDINAL . ORG In the case of ORG v. PERSON which came before ORG ( permanent NORP division ) , ORG made the following submissions ( translation ) :

" The auditeur militaire who chairs ORG discharges the judicial functions of an investigating judge ( PERSON . , CARDINAL DATE , RW [ Rechtskundig Weekblad ] , DATE , col . CARDINAL ) . LAW of DATE , taken together with LAW , lays on the chairman of ORG the duty to act as an independent judge , in particular in regard to the parties ( Cour mil . , DATE , ORG [ Revue de droit pénal et de criminologie ] , DATE , p. CARDINAL ) .

It has been held by ORG that the judge or other officer authorised by law to exercise judicial power during preliminary investigations , and more particularly when an arrest warrant is issued , must be independent of the executive and of the parties ( Schiesser judgment , DATE , Series A , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE ) . As an investigating judge , the auditeur militaire is independent of the executive , as under LAW of DATE ) he is only subject to the supervision and direction of the auditeur général when discharging his duties as a member of the public prosecutor ’s office .

ORG held in the cases of ORG and PERSON ( judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A , no . CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ) and PERSON , GPE and PERSON ( judgment , CARDINAL DATE , Series A , no . CARDINAL , § DATE ) that the NORP auditeur - militair , although independent of the military authorities , could not be independent of the parties during the preliminary stage of the trial because he was liable , at a subsequent stage , to become a party himself , in that instance as prosecuting authority .

Consequently , the NORP auditeur militaire , in that he intervenes as prosecuting authority , likewise does not afford the guarantees of impartiality and independence necessary for him to be able to perform the duties of investigating judge in the same case .
There is a danger that he might perform his duties as investigating judge from the point of view of the prosecuting authority at a subsequent stage of the proceedings .

This does not apply only to cases in which an arrest warrant is issued . The judicial function of investigating judge is indivisible and embraces all the judicial acts performed during a preliminary investigation .

The preliminary investigation and the prosecution must accordingly be conducted by different judicial officers ( Cour mil . , CARDINAL DATE , ORG , DATE , p. CARDINAL ) ; having a single judicial officer combine the functions of investigation and prosecution is incompatible with the impartiality and independence required of an investigating judge and accordingly violates Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL , article CARDINAL ) of LAW as construed by ORG in the above - mentioned cases .

The explicit provisions of LAW regarding judicial safeguards lay down rights which are distinct but stem from the same basic idea , namely a citizen ’s right to a fair trial ( PERSON judgment , DATE , Series A , no . CARDINAL , § LAW and DATE ) . This basic right in a NORP society , as laid down in the LAW , has such a prominent place that a narrow interpretation of the Convention ’s explicit provisions in this field would not be in accordance with the ORG ’s object and purpose ( FAC judgment , DATE , Series A , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) . CARDINAL of the vital prerequisites of the right to a fair trial is precisely that the preliminary investigation and the prosecution should be separate , and LAW article CARDINAL ) of the LAW is but an application of this principle .

In the present case the same judicial officer combined the functions of investigating judge with those of public prosecutor , firstly - as chairman of ORG and with the military members of ORG - by ordering a report to be made by an expert and hearing the accused during the final questioning , and subsequently by participating in the trial as prosecutor .

This amounts to a violation of ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL , article CARDINAL ) of LAW and is consequently unlawful in NORP domestic law ( PERSON . , CARDINAL DATE , Pas . [ Pasicrisie ] , DATE , CARDINAL ) .

The investigative measures taken in the PERSON case - the appointment of an expert and the final hearing of the accused by ORG - should therefore be declared null and void and the documents relating to those measures ( including the expert ’s report ) should be declared inadmissible in evidence .

Ruling that these documents are inadmissible , however , does not in any way prevent the court from reaching a decision on the basis of the other evidence , namely the police reports and the accused ’s statements to the auditeur militaire acting as senior police officer ( officier de police judiciaire ) .
For these reasons ,
Having regard to LAW , Articles DATE of the Code of Military Criminal Procedure and Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL , article CARDINAL ) of LAW of DATE ) ,
I ask the court ,

firstly , to declare that the appointment of an expert by ORG and the Board ’s final hearing of the accused ( item CARDINAL in the file on the expert ’s report and items CARDINAL and CARDINAL in the file on the preliminary investigation ) together with the expert ’s report are null and void and to rule these items inadmissible in evidence ;
secondly , to order the costs of the expert ’s report to be paid by the ORG ; and

thirdly , taking its decision on the basis of the other evidence , to convict the accused in accordance with my oral submissions . " ( Journal des tribunaux , no . CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE , pp . CARDINAL - CARDINAL )
On DATE , ORG gave its judgment , which included the following reasons ( translated from the NORP original ) :

" The auditeur général ’s office took the view that , as the same senior deputy auditeur militaire acted both as investigating judge and as prosecutor , several items relating to the investigative measures must be declared null and void and inadmissible in evidence , because the investigation and the prosecution must be conducted by different judicial officers .
Every citizen has a right to a fair trial , and CARDINAL of the vital prerequisites of the right to a fair trial is that the preliminary investigation and the prosecution shall be separate .

ORG has so held ( FAC case , judgment of DATE , Series A , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) , and ORG has likewise so decided on several occasions ( judgments of CARDINAL DATE , Pub . v. D ... and Pub . Pros . v. R ... and others , PERSON . GPE [ Jurisprudence de la cour d’appel de Liège ] , DATE , pp . CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .
For these reasons :
THE COURT ,
Declares the appeals admissible ;
Holds that ORG appointment of an expert , the final hearing of the defendant by ORG and the expert ’s report are null and void and must be excluded as inadmissible evidence ;
Sets aside the decision appealed against in so far as it ordered the defendant to pay the costs of the expert opinion ( CARDINAL F ) ;
Orders the ORG to pay the costs of the expert opinion ;
... " ( ibid . , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , the auditeur général submitted to the Minister of ORG a new preliminary draft Code of Military Criminal Procedure which had been drawn up by an inter - departmental committee . CARDINAL of its purposes was to prevent any plurality of functions in the person of the auditeur militaire in peace time by creating CARDINAL categories of military judicial officer , namely auditeurs militaires , who would retain only the powers of public prosecutors , and judges , who would deal with preliminary investigations as chairmen of ORG .

According to the report submitted by Mr. PERSON on behalf of ORG , the existing LAW " has now been overtaken , in a number of fundamental respects , both by changes in human - rights case - law and by the new patterns of organisation entailed by the separation of preliminary investigation and prosecution " ( PERSON CARDINAL-VI ( DATE ) no . CARDINAL of DATE , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG When constituted at the seat of ORG , ORG comprises - in addition to the auditeur militaire ( or deputy auditeur militaire ) , who chairs it - CARDINAL officers ( officiers commissaires ) appointed by the area commanding officer from among the officers of the garrison , normally for DATE . They are appointed in turn and in order of seniority ( Articles CARDINAL of the LAW ) .
The auditeur militaire is the sole permanent member of ORG . Th military members of ORG are changed frequently , on the expiry of their term of office or as operational needs require .

CARDINAL . ORG The ORG conducts the written part of the investigation of the case ( LAW ) . In carrying out its task , it may issue a warrant for the arrest of a person who has been brought before the auditeur militaire . In such cases it must , at least once a month , review the detention in question ( auditeur général ’s Circular no . CARDINAL of DATE , paragraph III ( e)(CARDINAL ) ) . In addition , it may at any time order the accused ’s release on condition that he appear in person at any stage in the proceedings as soon as he is asked to do so ( LAW ) .

By LAW , the auditeur militaire " shall direct the investigation " . He must endeavour as much to establish the accused ’s innocence as to obtain evidence of his guilt and secure a confession ( LAW ) . The decisions of ORG are his sole responsibility , and any dissenting opinions of the CARDINAL officer members of ORG are not binding on him . The function of these CARDINAL members is merely to assist him , not as investigating judges but as technical advisers and as witnesses to the lawfulness of the investigation , which they guarantee by their presence and by their signature .

CARDINAL . Responsibility for conducting the prosecution lies with the public prosecutor , in other words the auditeur militaire ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , and not with ORG . It falls to ORG to determine at the end of the investigation whether there is sufficient evidence to justify committal for trial , but the summons requiring the accused to appear before ORG is issued by the auditeur militaire or one of his deputies . On issue of the summons ORG ceases to have jurisdiction .
